articles.title: Surprise ‘tail’ found on an iconic galaxy may rewrite its history
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 07 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03665-6First image from Vera C. Rubin telescope reveals a previously unnoticed feature of galaxy M61 that may explain its mysterious properties.
articles.content:
Galaxy M61 sports a long stellar stream, which had not been spotted before now.Credit: NSF–DOE Vera C. Rubin Observatory/NOIRLab/SLAC/AURA/A. Romanowsky et. al. Mere months after its long-awaited debut, the Vera C. Rubin Observatory is beginning to deliver on its promise to rewrite cosmic history. The observatory’s colossal camera — perched atop a mountain in Chile — has yet to begin its official scientific survey. But just by perusing its first test image, astronomers have uncovered a surprise: a trail of light — called a stellar stream — extending from a well-known galaxy, suggesting that the galaxy once tore apart a much smaller one.

“This is the first stellar stream detected from Rubin,” says Sarah Pearson, an astrophysicist at the University of Copenhagen. “And it’s just a precursor for all of the many, many features we’ll find like this.” The authors reported their findings in the Research Notes of the American Astronomical Society1.

A tail that tells tales

The galaxy, named Messier 61, was first spotted in 1779 in the Virgo Cluster of galaxies and has caught the gaze of astronomers ever since. Hosting a slew of supernovae and churning out new stars at a surprisingly high rate, Messier 61 is what’s known as a starburst galaxy owing to its bounty of stellar activity.

Astronomers have enlisted some powerhouse telescopes — including the James Webb Space Telescope and the Hubble Space Telescope — to unravel the galaxy’s structure. But “despite all of this intense study, no one had ever found this stellar stream”, says Aaron Romanowsky, an astronomer at San Jose State University in California and an author of the study.

This finding has broad implications for understanding galaxy formation and cosmic history, representing a meaningful breakthrough in space science with potential wide-reaching impact for the general public's knowledge of the universe.
articles.personality_title: New ‘tail’ discovered on galaxy M61 sheds light on its past
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Vera C. Rubin Observatory, a powerful new telescope in Chile, recently began testing its camera before starting its main scientific work. It aims to explore the universe in more detail than ever before.

**What happened** – In its first test image, the observatory spotted a long, faint stream of stars stretching from a famous galaxy called Messier 61 (M61). This stream, known as a stellar stream, had never been seen before. It suggests that M61 once pulled apart a smaller galaxy, leaving behind this trail of stars.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it changes what scientists know about M61’s history. Even though M61 has been studied with other big telescopes like Hubble and James Webb, this new feature was hidden until now. Finding the stellar stream helps explain why M61 forms stars so quickly and may reveal how galaxies grow by merging with smaller ones.

**What's next step** – Astronomers will continue using the Vera C. Rubin Observatory to look for more hidden features in other galaxies. This discovery is just the beginning, and many more surprising details about our universe might be uncovered soon.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Vera C. Rubin Observatory’s first image revealed a hidden stellar stream in galaxy M61, offering new clues about how galaxies evolve over time.

articles.personality_title_es: Descubren una nueva ‘cola’ en la galaxia M61 que revela su historia
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Observatorio Vera C. Rubin, un nuevo telescopio potente en Chile, comenzó recientemente a probar su cámara antes de iniciar su trabajo científico principal. Su objetivo es explorar el universo con más detalle que nunca.

**Qué pasó** – En su primera imagen de prueba, el observatorio detectó una larga y tenue corriente de estrellas que se extiende desde una galaxia famosa llamada Messier 61 (M61). Esta corriente, llamada corriente estelar, nunca antes había sido vista. Sugiere que M61 alguna vez desgarró una galaxia más pequeña, dejando este rastro de estrellas.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque cambia lo que los científicos saben sobre la historia de M61. Aunque M61 ha sido estudiada con otros grandes telescopios como Hubble y James Webb, esta nueva característica estaba oculta hasta ahora. Encontrar la corriente estelar ayuda a explicar por qué M61 forma estrellas tan rápido y puede mostrar cómo las galaxias crecen al fusionarse con galaxias más pequeñas.

**Próximo paso** – Los astrónomos seguirán usando el Observatorio Vera C. Rubin para buscar más características ocultas en otras galaxias. Este descubrimiento es solo el comienzo, y pronto podrían descubrirse muchos más detalles sorprendentes sobre nuestro universo.

**Resumen en una frase** – La primera imagen del Observatorio Vera C. Rubin reveló una corriente estelar oculta en la galaxia M61, ofreciendo nuevas pistas sobre cómo evolucionan las galaxias con el tiempo.
